problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: An indicator is usually a weak acid or base whose colour changes because its undissociated and dissociated forms have different colours. Which statement describes this behaviour correctly?
options: Only its undissociated form exists in solution
Both forms have the same colour
Colour changes due to equilibrium between its forms
Colour changes only because pH changes colour of water
problems.hint: Think about dissociation equilibrium of the indicator.
problems.detailed: An indicator (weak acid/base) dissociates: \(\ce{HIn <=> H^+ + In^-}\). The undissociated and dissociated forms have different colours, so colour depends on which form predominates.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: If an indicator has \(\ce{pK_a}\) = 5, in which approximate pH range will its transition (colour change) occur?
problems.detailed: Transition range = \(5 \pm 1\) → pH 4 to 6. So around that range the indicator changes colour.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: Which colour (form) of the indicator predominates in acidic solution if the undissociated form \(\ce{HIn}\) has colour A and the dissociated form \(\ce{In^-}\) has colour B?
options: Colours A and B are equal
problems.detailed: High \([H^+]\) shifts the equilibrium \(\ce{HIn <=> H^+ + In^-}\) to the left → more undissociated \(\ce{HIn}\) which has colour A. So colour A predominates.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: What factor is needed for selecting an indicator for a titration to detect the equivalence point accurately?
options: Indicator whose transition range is completely above pH 10
Indicator whose transition range matches equivalence point pH
problems.hint: Colour change needs to occur close to equivalence point.
problems.detailed: For titration, the equivalence point’s pH should lie within (or near) the transition range of the indicator so the colour change happens around the correct moment.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: In a basic solution, which form of the indicator predominates if the indicator behaves as a weak acid \(\ce{HIn}\)?
problems.hint: In basic solution, \([\ce{OH}^-]\) is high so \([\ce{H}^+]\) is low.
problems.detailed: The equilibrium of the indicator is \(\ce{HIn <=> H+ + In^-}\). In basic solution, \([\ce{H}^+]\) is reduced because \(\ce{OH^-}\) neutralizes it, so the equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more \(\ce{In^-}\). Therefore, the dissociated form predominates and its color is observed.
